Now the temptation to swap knights before Black was defending it with Q or B was too strong.
With this move, I chose my strategy of harassing Black's queenside, exploiting the hole at b6.  I think last time we played I attacked in the centre.

So now I recentralise my knight.  I was not concerned by the prospect of Black doubling my c-pawn as that would cost him his fianchettoed KB.
Black now prepares a counter-attack with ...d5 and, as I saw quite late, threatens ...Nc4, followed by ....Nxe3 and ...Bd4 or by ...Nxb2 and ...Bxc3
So the Q returned to e2.

?!  I didn't really believe in this as I played it and it didn't really help but I couldn't find anything else.  Curiously, I noticed that this was my first pawn move since my opening three pawn moves.  In contrast, Black had already made 8 pawn moves.
